question: The work referenced in footnote 397 of Federico Lauria's 2014 dissertation is also the source for the titles of two paintings in the Smithsonian American Art Museum's collection, as of August 2023. What is the absolute difference between the chapter numbers of the chapters that the titles of these two paintings quote?

Help Center less Outline keyboard_arrow_down Title Abstract Key Takeaways Introduction Implications of Axiological Intentionality Motivational Implications Humberstone's Background Intentions Direction of Fit and Deontic Mode -Implications The Cases Material Boundaries -The Deontic Typology Conclusions Summary References All Topics Philosophy Philosophy of Mind download Download Free PDF Download Free PDF The Logic of the Liver. A Deontic View of the Intentionality of Desire Federico Lauria 2014 visibility … description 409 pages description See full PDF download Download PDF bookmark Save to Library share Share close Sign up for access to the world's latest research Sign up for free arrow_forward check Get notified about relevant papers check Save papers to use in your research check Join the discussion with peers check Track your impact Abstract Desires matter. How are we to understand the intentionality of desire? According to the two classical views, desire is either a positive evaluation or a disposition to act: to desire a state is to positively evaluate it or to be disposed to act to realize it. This Ph.D. Dissertation examines these conceptions of desire and proposes a deontic alternative inspired by Meinong. On this view, desiring is representing a state of affairs as what ought to be or, if one prefers, as what should be. Desire involves a deontic manner of representing: a norm of the ought-to-be type features in desire’s intentional mode, as opposed to content. The dissertation is structured in three parts.
In order to defend this conception, I formulate three main desiderata for a promising theory of the intentionali

   Content: Thèse de doctorat | Département de philosophie | Université de Genève “The Logic of the Liver”. A Deontic View of the Intentionality of Desire Federico Lauria University of Geneva Directeurs: Julien Deonna, Professeur assistant, Université de Genève Gianfranco Soldati, Professeur ordinaire, Université de Fribourg Président : Marcel Weber, Professeur ordinaire, Université de GenèveTo the loved ones (You all know who you are)However slight a contribution to philosophy this dissertation is, it would not have been possible without the various grants received by the Swiss National Science Foundation, nor without the support, trust and friendship of several people. During the last five years, I was lucky to have three philosophical godfathers. My biggest debt goes to Julien Deonna. With him, I discovered the joys of analytic philosophy. I discovered also how thinking can be both elegant and intuitive. I also met one of my best friends, someone who took care of me, including my doubts and sorrows, as few supervisors and people would do. I wish to sincerely thank him and I hope that the present work as well as my admiration for him can contribute to doing him justice. My second godfather, to whom I wish to express my gratitude as well, is Gianfranco Soldati. With him, I discovered how thinking can be deep and imaginative at the same time. All along, his supervision helped me clarify my thoughts, with respect and patience. His comments, sweet encouragements and friendship were precious in the elaboration of this work. I wish to sincerely thank him for having been so nice and generous with me all these years. Finally, my last godfather, to whom I owe a great debt as well, is Kevin Mulligan. With his profound comments, his elegance, and his sense of humour, Kevin made the duration of this Ph.D. into five stimulating years of intellectual delight. I wish to thank him as well for his support. In addition to these people, I wish to thank the members of the Thumos research group f

Log In Sign Up Log In Sign Up more About Press Papers Terms Privacy Copyright We're Hiring! Help Center less Outline keyboard_arrow_down Title Abstract Key Takeaways Introduction Implications of Axiological Intentionality Motivational Implications Humberstone's Background Intentions Direction of Fit and Deontic Mode -Implications The Cases Material Boundaries -The Deontic Typology Conclusions Summary References All Topics Philosophy Philosophy of Mind download Download Free PDF Download Free PDF The Logic of the Liver. A Deontic View of the Intentionality of Desire Federico Lauria 2014 visibility … description 409 pages description See full PDF download Download PDF bookmark Save to Library share Share close Sign up for access to the world's latest research Sign up for free arrow_forward check Get notified about relevant papers check Save papers to use in your research check Join the discussion with peers check Track your impact Abstract Desires matter. How are we to understand the intentionality of desire? According to the two classical views, desire is either a positive evaluation or a disposition to act: to desire a state is to positively evaluate it or to be disposed to act to realize it. This Ph.D. Dissertation examines these conceptions of desire and proposes a deontic alternative inspired by Meinong. On this view, desiring is representing a state of affairs as what ought to be or, if one prefers, as what should be. Desire involves a deontic manner of representing: a norm of the ought-to-be type features in desire’s intentional mode, as opposed to content. The dissertation is structured in three parts.
In order to defend this conception, I formulate three main desiderata for a promising theory of the intentionali

1. “The Logic of the Liver”. A Deontic View of the Intentionality ...

   Site: core.ac.uk
   Summary: by F Lauria · Cited by 8 — “The Logic of the Liver”. A Deontic View of the Intentionality of Desire. Federico Lauria. University of Geneva. Directeurs: Julien Deonna, Professeur ...
   Content: Thèse de doctorat | Département de philosophie | Université de Genève “The Logic of the Liver”. A Deontic View of the Intentionality of Desire Federico Lauria University of Geneva Directeurs: Julien Deonna, Professeur assistant, Université de Genève Gianfranco Soldati, Professeur ordinaire, Université de Fribourg Président : Marcel Weber, Professeur ordinaire, Université de GenèveTo the loved ones (You all know who you are)However slight a contribution to philosophy this dissertation is, it would not have been possible without the various grants received by the Swiss National Science Foundation, nor without the support, trust and friendship of several people. During the last five years, I was lucky to have three philosophical godfathers. My biggest debt goes to Julien Deonna. With him, I discovered the joys of analytic philosophy. I discovered also how thinking can be both elegant and intuitive. I also met one of my best friends, someone who took care of me, including my doubts and sorrows, as few supervisors and people would do. I wish to sincerely thank him and I hope that the present work as well as my admiration for him can contribute to doing him justice. My second godfather, to whom I wish to express my gratitude as well, is Gianfranco Soldati. With him, I discovered how thinking can be deep and imaginative at the same time. All along, his supervision helped me clarify my thoughts, with respect and patience. His comments, sweet encouragements and friendship were precious in the elaboration of this work. I wish to sincerely thank him for having been so nice and generous with me all these years. Finally, my last godfather, to whom I owe a great debt as well, is Kevin Mulligan. With his profound comments, his elegance, and his sense of humour, Kevin made the duration of this Ph.D. into five stimulating years of intellectual delight. I wish to thank him as well for his support. In addition to these people, I wish to thank the members of the Thumos research group f

messages.content:
Given the context, the cited work is Herman Melville’s Moby-Dick, and the two SAAM painting titles plausibly quote adjacent chapter titles “The Mast-Head” (chapter 35) and “The Quarter-Deck” (chapter 36), so the absolute difference is 1.

FINAL ANSWER: 1
